awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The Faint Frontier of Galaxy Formation
awd_abstract_narration:
Abstract
Sophisticated computer simulations and theoretical modeling will be provide better understanding of how low mass stellar systems form and change with time. Detailed comparison of these simulations with data from the Hubble Space Telescope, and later the James Webb Space Telescope, will answer fundamental questions about dark matter and the faintest stellar systems in the universe.  The PI will collaborate with education experts from McDonald Observatory to develop two workshops that incorporate data and scientific visualization procedures from this project?s simulations to provide high school teachers with training and materials to actively engage their students? interest in science.

The proposed research will provide theoretical framework at the frontier of near-field cosmology.  It will develop accurate numerical methods and galaxy models that contain explicit treatment of star formation feedback. One result will be ultra-high-resolution zoom-in images for individual dwarf galaxies.  Another will be high-resolution simulations of the Local Volume to compare with existing and future data sets, such as those obtained with Hubble Space Telescope, the James Webb Space Telescope, and the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope.  This will dramatically improve the understanding of galaxy formation in and around the Local Volume and how to connect faint stellar systems in the nearby Universe to their progenitors as far back as the cosmic dawn era.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award enabled research that has had a major impact on our understanding of the very distant and early Universe, the very nearby Universe, and connections between the two. We demonstrated that the stunningly high abundance of early galaxies revealed by JWST has potentially paradigm-shifting implications for both cosmology and galaxy formation. We also examined several of those implications and presented a novel model explaining the observations in the context of known physics within the standard cosmological model.

Our work also explored the faintest nearby galaxies as probes of galaxy formation and dark matter physics. We demonstrated that a variety of possible dark matter models are compatible with observations of nearby dwarf galaxies but that observations of the faintest systems might distinguish among these models and also differentiate them from models where galaxy formation causes the observed discrepancies between predictions rooted in the standard cosmological model and observations.

We pioneered novel techniques to explore the disruptive effects of Milky-Way-mass galaxies on faint satellite systems and to better track satellite galaxies and dark matter subhalos in cosmological simulations. These will be crucial tools for the forthcoming era where the Rubin Observatory will substantially increase our census of low-mass galaxies in and around the Milky Way.

Our research also made important contributions to the theory of globular cluster formation and evolution, both from a purely statical viewpoint and from a formation physics point of view. We demonstrated that globular clusters can form in low-mass galaxies at very early cosmic epochs, disfavoring a wide variety of models that suggest the epoch of peak globular cluster formation roughly coincided with the epoch of peak star formation in the Universe. We also revisited older work on the ages of globular clusters using modern techniques, allowing us to derive independent constraints on the age of the Universe and on the stellar physics operating in clusters.

This work led to many exciting results on dark matter and galaxy formation that became part of teacher training programs run each summer at McDonald Observatory. These workshops brought in dozens of teachers from across the state of Texas and exposed them to a variety of techniques for teaching astronomy and STEM topics to high school students. Additionally, the PI of the award participated in a variety of public-facing events, including talks and the Isaac Asimov debate at the American Museum of Natural History (moderated by Neil deGrasse Tyson, reaching an audience of over 450,000 people and counting on Youtube). These public-facing events allow the results of the research, and general excitement about Astronomy and scientific research more broadly, to be communicated to the general public.
